newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia's Wills sues Philip Morris over new brand.
newsitem.headline: Australia's Wills sues Philip Morris over new brand.

text.p: Australian cigarette maker W.D. & H.O. Wills Ltd said on Monday it had launched legal action against U.S. tobacco giant Philip Morris for misleading and deceptive conduct over a key Wills cigarette brand, Horizon.

Wills said it discovered last week that Philip Morris planned to launch a cigarette brand packaged almost identically to Horizon in terms of colour, lettering and imagery and accused it of trying to 'pass off' the new brand as Horizon.
Wills said Horizon had been the fastest growing cigarette brand in the Australian market and had achieved a 14 percent market share since its launch in 1991.
"We will use every available means to protect Horizon from attack by this me-too product," Wills corporate communications manager Catherine Byrne said in a statement.
The two companies will first meet in court on Wednesday, a Philip Morris Australia Ltd spokeswoman said.
"We have considered the material provided (by Wills) and have briefed our lawyers," Philip Morris Australia's corporate affairs manager, Nerida White, told Reuters.

Wills, 67 percent owned by Britain's B.A.T. Industries Plc, made a A$13.27 million ($US10.1 million) profit in calendar 1996 in a turnaround from a loss of A$5.16 million in 1995 caused by a price war.

The head of Philip Morris's Australian subsidiary, Henry Goldberg, said in April that he expected another cigarette price war to erupt in Australia by June that could cost the sector A$100 million in earnings in 1997.
Rothmans Australia Ltd is the other main cigarette maker in Australia.
